Depends on the decision of the manufacturer in agreement with
the operator.

Must be arranged to allow at least 50% of all passengers to
leave the aeroplane within 2 minutes.

Must be in accordance with the number of passengers on
board.

options.text: its own certificate issued in accordance with this regulation.
the competent authority of an EASA member state.

options.text: An operator shall ensure that air traffic services are used for all flights whenever available.
The operator can deem ATC unnecessary for a flight if disregarding ATC gives commercial benefits.
The commander can choose whether to use ATC or not.

variant.question: When refuelling is being conducted with passengers embarking or disembarking:

options.text: communications shall be maintained by ground crew and qualified crew on board.
all flight crew must be on board.
refuelling is strictly prohibited whilst passengers are embarking/disembarking.
the stairs shall be fully extended.

There must be a door, and it must be lockable.

There need not be a door, and it need not be
lockable.

There must be a door, but it need not be
lockable.

variant.question: The commander shall declare an emergency when the:

options.text: calculated usable fuel on landing, at the nearest adequate aerodrome where a safe landing can be performed, is less than final reserve fuel.
calculated landing fuel will be lower than the specified minimum within the flight/OPS manual.
calculated usable fuel on landing, at the nearest adequate aerodrome where a safe landing can be performed, is less than for 30 minutes flight time.
calculated landing fuel at the destination airport is lower than the alternate plus final reserve.

variant.question: In accordance with EASA AIR OPS and if required, the number of life rafts to be carried on board an aircraft must allow the transportation of the entire aircraft occupants:

in the case of a loss of two rafts.

options.text: is allowed, but all flight crew members have to stay at their designated position.
is allowed if fire fighters are ready to fight any fire.
is allowed if the place outside of the emergency exits is clear, so that the slides could deploy in an emergency.

variant.question:
For a pressurized aircraft, flying at FL240 with 150 passengers on board, the regulatory oxygen requirements are:   
 
1. Each flight crew member shall be supplied with a quick donning oxygen mask.
2. The aircraft will be equipped with a warning system indicating that the cabin altitude is higher than 3 000m.
3. The quantity of oxygen on board shall be sufficient for the supply of 100% of the passengers during the whole flight time at cabin pressure altitude above 15 000 ft (not less than 10 minutes).
4. The first aid quantity of oxygen shall be sufficient for the supply of three passengers during the whole flight time when the cabin altitude is greater than 8 000 feet.

options.text: To prevent acts of unlawful interference.
To be able to analyse risks.
Training cabin crew on how to basically fly the airplane in case of flight crew incapacitation.

options.text: Passengers, crew, ground personnel, and the general public.
All areas of the airport on the airside, especially around the aircraft parking areas.
The aircraft, passengers, crew and ground personnel airside only.
All airport buildings, especially the passenger terminals and waiting areas within.

options.text: Report the event as an occurrence involving undeclared dangerous goods.
Make an immediate forced landing as the lighter fuel poses a serious fire risk.

command an immediate evacuation advising crew and passengers to use all available aircraft exits.

variant.question:
An aeroplane is planned to perform a short flight where the maximum planned altitude is FL260. During flight preparations, the crew realises that the aeroplane is NOT RVSM compliant due to a technical malfunction that has been deferred to the MEL.
What, if any, altitude restrictions apply for the flight?

options.text: None, as the flight is planned to operate below RVSM airspace.
A lower altitude must be planned, below FL200, because the aeroplane CANNOT fly at FL260 until the technical malfunction is repaired.
The planned minimum flight altitude must be increased to ensure adequate obstacle clearance.
The aeroplane is NOT airworthy and the flight CANNOT be completed.

options.text: The contracted organisation under an oversight programme established by the competent authority.

variant.question:
During boarding, a visually impaired passenger notifies the cabin crew that his/her accompanying passenger has been assigned a seat away from him/her. options.text: NOT be assigned these seats as direct access to the emergency exit could be impeded.

Be assigned these seats on boarding, but must be reassigned during the landing phase because of an increased risk of an evacuation.
Be assigned these seats because the accompanying passenger must be able to assist the PRM in case of an emergency.

options.text: Provide to that person the documentation required to be carried on board.

Comply because anybody is allowed to see those documents.
